field_edited_text.value:
Policy:
Identify and develop new access

points for the public to the
waterfront.

Policy:
Develop continuous public access

along the shoreline in residential and
commercial areas where feasible.

Policy:

Create increased opportunities for
the public to view shipping and
industrial activities located on the
harbor.

Policy:

The City should work with owners of
shorefront land to remove derelict
piers and structures, clear debris,
rectify shoreline erosion, improve
existing buildings and landscape
edges where feasible.

Access to the shoreline can take on
many forms and sizes. While the City will
continue to develop large scale plans for
promenades in the Inner Harbor and Falls
Harbor, there are numerous sites in the har-
bor to develop small scale access points.
Two such sites are under development. At
Hull Street and Boston Street the City has
developed small boating piers and
improved the water’s edge for local resi-
dents. The City will continue to identify
small scale opportunities for public access
to the shoreline.

The City should seek to provide public
access along the shoreline in new or rehabil-
itated residential projects and commercial
buildings on the harbor. This policy has
been successfully implemented in the Inner
Harbor and plans are under development to
continue access in new projects along Piers
4,5, and 6 and to the east in Falls Harbor.

This policy has already been incorpo-
rated into development proposals and the
Federal permits for several projects in Fells
Point and along Boston Street. Public access
to the water has become an important con-
sideration in the review of all residential
and commercial projects along the harbor’s
shoreline.

Other port cities have found that many
people are fascinated by port and industrial
operations and have provided facilities from
which they can view activities safely. The
City has requested the MPA to include such
a facility, perhaps an observation tower, in
its proposed Masonville Marine Terminal.
Other opportunities should be identified
and developed.

An increasing number of people visit
or tour our City via its harbor and a greater
effort must be undertaken to clean-up the
water’s edge. Debris from unkept shorelines
and piers is not only unsightly but provides
a hazard to boaters and shipping. Erosion
causes both landside problems as buildings
and roads are undermined and problems in
the water as sediment fills in channels and
reduces water quality. In cases where ero-
sion or derlict piers are a navigation or pol-
lution problem the City should assist owners
in working with the appropriate State or
Federal agency. Many industrial buildings
located on the waterfront are now highly
visable from the water. It is in their best
interest to improve buildings and shoreline
visable to the public. The City may also
secure funds to remove piers and sunken
boats if they present a hazard to navigation.







Public shoreline walk, Fort Armistead



106
